projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2010-09 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images

div.p: Clough, 1700.

THE New England ALMANACK For the Year of our LORD, MDCC From the CREATION 5649. And From the Diſcovery of America by Chr. Columbus, 208. Being Leap Year, & of the Reign of our Gracious Sovereign, King WILLIAM the Third (which began Febr. the 13. 1688,9) the 12th.

Wherein is contained the ſeveral • changes of the Moon, and Aſpects of the Planets, Courts, Spring Tides, Riſeing & Setting of the Sun, with the Sun & Moons place, and time of Full Sea •
or High Water, with an account of the Eclipſes: And a figure of the Viſible Eclipſe as it will appear to us.

The Vulgar Notes of this year are,
Golden Number 10
The Epact 20
Cicle of the Sun 1
Dominic Letters G. F.
Fitted to the Meridian of Boſton in New-England Lat. 42. gr. 30. min. But may ſerve any part of New-England without any ſenſible Error.
By Samuel Clough, A Lover of the Mathematicks.
•• ſton, Printed by Bartholomew Green, & John Allen Sold at the Printing-Houſe. 1700.

THou art here preſented with an Almanack, it being the fruit of my ſpare hours this laſt Summer, the Compoſure of which was at the deſire of the Printer. Having ever ſince I came to years of underſtanding taken much delight in the Mathematicks, I have for my ••… cy ſtudyed ſomething of it, though not ſo much as to •… it my ſelf either profeſſor or practitioner, yet a Reader • nd lover of it: therefore I deſire a favourable cenſure from the Learned, ſhould there be miſtakes; tho' I think there are none that are eſſential, conſidering it is the firſt of my Attempts thus to appear in publick. Notwithſtanding, if this be well accepted it may encourage me to make ſome further experiment this way yearly, accommodated with ſomething new.

Reader, As for the Weather, I deſire a very favourable conſtruction; it is againſt my mind to put any ſuch thing in, but conſidering the People have been us'd to it in the Almanacks of late, I have ſet it down to gratify thoſe that deſire it. I would not have any be ſo Rul'd by it as to expect juſt ſuch weather always on the days againſt which it is ſet, tho' it is poſſible it may ſo happen; for the very Rules that the foretelling of the w ••
ther is grounded upon are not to be truſted to or ••
pended upon; for certain it is that the times & ſeaſo •• are in the Hand of God alone, and He changes them 〈◊〉 He pleaſeth. Indeed this we may know certainly 〈…〉
div.l: That if the Air be fair and clear,
Then will the ways more clean appear:
But if it chance to Snow or Rain,
Then they will dirty be again.
div.p: ☞ Note, At what time & places the Inferiour Court 〈…〉 alſo hold Courts of General Seſſions of the 〈…〉

div.head: JANUARY hath 31 Dayes.
div.l: Laſt quart. 1 day. 51 min paſt 10 morn
New moon 9 day 50 min paſt 11 morn
Firſt quart. 17 day 27 min paſt 9 morn
Full m 24 d 28 m p 4 morn Laſt q 31 d 38 m p 2 morn

l.hi: Beware of Cold, to bleed or purge take heed,
A good Warm Coat this Month thy back will need.

div.head: FEBRUARY hath 29 Dayes
div.l: New moon 8 day 55 min paſt 6 afternoon
Firſt quart 16 day 33 min paſt 12 noon
Full moon 23 day 46 min paſt 2 morn

l.hi: Warm Cloaths this Month are good, good drink no leſs,
Always provided thou avoid exceſs.

div.head: MARCH hath 31 Dayes.
div.l: Laſt quart. 1 day 14 min p. 8 morn
New moon 9 day 52 min paſt 11 beforenoon
Firſt quart. 16 day 58 min paſt 8 morn
Full m 23 d 5 m p 1 aftern. Laſt q 31 d 57 m p 2 morn

l.hi: Thy Blood afreſh 'gins to increaſe again,
Now bleed and purge thy Body to maintain.

row.cell: Inſ. Court Ply. North. & Edg Town
Sup. Court Ply. & Inf. C. Ipſw Nk.

div.head: APRIL hath 30 Dayes.
div.l: New moon 8 day 42 min paſt 1 morn
Firſt quart 15 day 27 min paſt 2 morn
Full moon 22 day 24 min paſt 2 morn
Laſt quart 29 day 46 min paſt 8 night

l.hi: If thou intendest for to purge or bleed,
Of Learn'd Phyſicians counſel thou haſt need.

div.head: MAY hath 31 Dayes.
div.l: New moon 7 day 56 min paſt noon
Firſt quart. 14 day 46 min paſt 6 morn
Full moon 21 day 30 min paſt noon
Laſt quart. 29 day 30 min paſt 1 afternoon

l.hi: Sweet morning walks this Month the minds may pleeſe,
Of them whoſe Bodies are in health and eaſe.

row.cell: Sup. Court Ipſwich and Inf. C.

div.head: JUNE hath 30. Dayes.
div.l: New moon 5 day 50 min paſt 9 night
Firſt quart. 12 day 58 min paſt 11 beforen.
Full moon 20 day 49 min paſt 1 morn
Laſt quart. 28 day 34 min paſt 4 morn

l.hi: Drinks new or ſweet, hot ſpice, I warn thee flie,

lg.l: The ſports of Venus and Plebotomy.

div.head: JULY hath 31 Dayes.
div.l: New moon 5 day 6 min paſt 5 morn
Firſt quart. 11 day 37 min paſt 7 night
Full moon 19 day 26 min paſt 4 aftern.
Laſt quart. 27 day 24 min paſt 6 afternoon.

l.hi: Strong Drink and new, refuſe; it is thy foe,

lg.l: To waſh in Rivers cool, this July goe.

div.head: AUGUST hath 31 Dayes.
div.l: New moon 3 day 31 min paſt noon
Firſt quart. 10 day 34 min paſt 6 morn
Full moon 18 day 6 min paſt 8 morn
Laſt quart. 26 day 26 min paſt 5 morn

l.hi: Take heed of Surfeits, and hot meats and Spices,
Phyſick forbear, be wiſe in exerciſes.

div.head: SEPTEMBER hath 30 Daye
div.l: New moon 1 day 18 min paſt 8 night
Firſt quart. 8 day 58 min paſt 8 night
Full moon 16 day 12 min paſt 12 night
Laſt quart. 24 day 44 min paſt 11 before

l.hi: Now Phyſick may be us'd, bleed, bathe and 〈◊〉
Or whatſoe're neceſſity doth urge.

row.cell: Sup. C. Briſtol & Inf. C Camb

div.head: OCTOBER hath 31 Dayes.
div.l: 〈◊〉 moon 1 day 20 min paſt 4 morn
〈◊〉 quart. 8 day 36 min paſt 2 aftern.
〈◊〉 moon 16 day 18 min paſt 4 aftern
〈◊◊〉 3 d. 9 m. p. 11 n. New m. 30 d. o m. p. 5. aftern

l.hi: Now Phyſicks help do not refuſe,
If thou it want and ſafely uſe.

row.cell: Inf. Court Boſton, Barnſt Wells E. T Nk.

div.head: NOVEMBER hath 30 Dayes.
div.l: Firſt quart. 7 day 34 min paſt 11 beforenoon
Full moon 15 day 24 min paſt 7 morn
Laſt quart. 22 day 57 min paſt 4 morn
New moon 29 day 14 min paſt 7 morn.

l.hi: Chooſe hot and wholeſome drinks, and meats likewiſe,
Avoid hot Baths, uſe honest exerciſe.

div.head: DECEMBER hath 31 Dayes.
div.l: Firſt quart. 7 day 58 min paſt 6 morn
Full moon 14 day 30 min paſt 8 night
Laſt quart. 21 day 37 min paſt 4 afternoon
New moon 29 day 37 min paſt 1 morn

l.hi: Now if thou haſt been prudent like the Ant,
Meat, Drink and Cloaths and Fire, thou wilt not want.

div.head: The Eclipſes 1700.
div.p: THis year there will happen but two Eclipſes, both which will be of the Moon, the firſt of them only will be Viſible to us in New-England (if the Weather be clear) which will be a Total Eclipſe, and according to Calculation will be as follows: On February the 23 day in the Morning.
The beginning of the Eclipſe will be at 17 min. 33 ſc. after midnight: The beginning of Total darkneſs 55 min 41 ſc. paſt 1 in the Morning.
The middle of the Eclipſe will be at 46 min. 9 ſc. paſt 2 in the Morning.
The end of Total darkneſs will be at 36 min. 37 ſc. paſt 3 in the Morning.
The end of the Eclipſe will be at 34 min. 45 ſc. paſt • in the Morning.
The whole Duration 3 hours 32 min. 18 ſc.
The Digits Eclipſed 20 & 46 min.
The Second will be on Auguſt the 18 about 9 in the forenoon therefore not Viſible to us, but in it ſelf will be a great Eclipſe.

div.head: Of the Four Seaſons or Quarters of the Year, 170 •
Of the Spring.
div.p: THe Spring Quarter begins when the Sun enters the firſt ſcruple of the vernal Equinoctial Sign Aries, making the days & nights of equal length all the world over, which will be on March the 9 the proper nature & quality of this Quarter is hot & moiſt, hot in reſpect of the Suns aſcending nearer to the Zenith, and moiſt in reſpect of the Winters Vicinity.
div.l: Now the Suns preſence begins to revive,
As well things ſenſible, as Vegetive.

div.head: Of the Summer.
div.p: The Summer Quarter begins the 10 of June, the Sun having then arrived to his greateſt Northen limits even to his Tropical Point Cancer, thereby making the longeſt days & ſhorteſt nights to all Northern Inhabitants in the World, the nature of this Seaſon is Hot and Dry.
div.l: Now Reapers panting both with heat and pain,
With crooked Razors ſhave the tufted plain.

div.head: Of Autumn.
div.p:
The Autumn Quarter begins the 12. of Sept. the Sun •• ing now returned from his greateſt Northen progreſs, • o his Autumnal Equinoctial Sign Libra, making again • days & nights of equ ••
•••• th: this Quarter is na
•• rally Cold and D •••
〈…〉
div.l: Now that 〈…〉
In theſe 〈…〉
